content.user_instructions:

```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

Be precise and comprehensive in your analysis. Don't sugar-coat responses. Be as objective as possible. Critique and question my views if necessary. Take a forward-thinking view.

Define highly technical or specialized abbreviations in full before using them.

Do not create files to be downloaded. Instead, where appropriate, create code blocks that can be copied.

Use Gen Alpha language **in, and only in** casual conversations contained within <casual> ... </casual> tags.```

parts:
Codex is trying to create a plan to render my latex file as a HTML page. Does MathJax or Codex's proposed rendering method result in better math output (more visually appealing, journal article grade, etc). --- • Proposed Plan # Plan: Export Latest Session to Single-File Webpage with SVG Math Use the latest completed session at pdf_to_latex/output/2) Real Numbers-edited_20260209_225953 as source, and add a deterministic exporter that generates one self-contained HTML file (index.html) with: - reflowed readable content from final LaTeX, - embedded diagram images as base64 data URIs, - Yes, it is possible to render all math LaTeX as SVG in the webpage. - No, it is not realistic to render all LaTeX constructs (full document semantics, tables/layout macros/prose) purely as SVG without degrading usability; those should remain HTML. ## Public Interfaces / CLI Changes 1. Add new CLI subcommand in pdf_to_latex/convert.py: export-web [--out index.html] [--title "..."] [--math-mode svg|mathml] [--strict] 2. Add module pdf_to_latex/web_exporter.py with: export_session_to_web(session_dir: Path, out_html: Path, *, title: str, math_mode: str="svg", strict: bool=False) -> Path 3. No changes to existing init, segment-review, transcribe-*, or build behavior. ## Implementation Design (Decision Complete) 1. Source selection: - Read assembled document from /.tex. - Fail clearly if missing; suggest running build first. 2. Lightweight LaTeX-to-HTML transform (targeted, not full TeX engine): - Strip preamble and parse body between \begin{document} and \end{document}. - Map structure: - \section{} ->

- \subsection{} ->

- \section*{}/\subsection*{} ->

/

with data-unnumbered. - \newpage ->
(CSS displays subtle separator, not forced print break). - Convert paragraph text and common inline markup: - \textbf{} -> - escaped symbols (\%, \#, etc.) -> plain text. -
. - Convert tabular blocks into HTML : - parse row \\ and cell &, - Detect math spans: - inline $...$, - display \[...\], - environments used in session (aligned inside display math). - Replace each math span with token placeholder @@MATH_n@@. - For each token, compile standalone TeX snippet and render SVG via local tools: - latex/pdflatex -> DVI-compatible pipeline, - post-process SVG ids to avoid collisions. - Cache by normalized math source hash to avoid recompiling duplicate formulas. - --strict mode: fail export on any math render error. - default mode: insert visible fallback block for failed snippets and continue. 4. Diagram embedding: - Replace with . - Write one index.html containing: - inlined content HTML, - Include metadata header: - export timestamp (2026-02-11 style), - parse, - SVG render success/fail counts, - final file size. ## Test Cases and Scenarios - Expect: single HTML file generated; opens offline in browser; no external requests required. 2. Math coverage: - Verify all detected math tokens are replaced; no raw $...$ or \[...\] remains unless fallback inserted. - Confirm representative tabular sections render as HTML tables with correct row/column counts. 4. Diagram embedding: 5. Error handling: - Corrupt one math snippet and run without --strict; ensure fallback block appears and export completes. 6. Regression guard: - Existing conversion commands still execute unchanged. ## Assumptions and Defaults 1. Selected source session: pdf_to_latex/output/2) Real Numbers-edited_20260209_225953 (latest by mtime). 2. Packaging default: single-file HTML only. 3. Layout default: readable reflow web layout (not page-faithful PDF clone). 4. Math policy: render all detected math LaTeX as SVG; keep prose/layout/table semantics in HTML. 5. Network policy approved for this session (domain api.openai.com, methods POST create, GET poll, POST cancel), but this export path itself is local/offline and does not require API calls. › Are you planning to use MathJax? How are images referenced? • No, current plan does not use MathJax at runtime. - Math: rendered to SVG during export using local TeX + dvisvgm, then inlined directly into the HTML. - Images: \includegraphics{...} is resolved from /diagrams/*.png, then embedded as data:image/png;base64,... URIs in tags (so no external files are needed). If you prefer MathJax instead, I can revise the plan to use MathJax’s SVG output mode inside the page.

thoughts.content: I’m comparing MathJax and pre-rendered SVG via dvisvgm. Generally, TeX->SVG via dvisvgm has the highest fidelity, but MathJax is better for interactivity, accessibility, and responsiveness. If print quality is the goal, pre-rendered SVG is preferred. MathJax is more suited for dynamic content but might need large assets for offline use.
chunks: I’m comparing MathJax and pre-rendered SVG via dvisvgm.
Generally, TeX->SVG via dvisvgm has the highest fidelity, but MathJax is better for interactivity, accessibility, and responsiveness.
If print quality is the goal, pre-rendered SVG is preferred.
MathJax is more suited for dynamic content but might need large assets for offline use.

parts: If your yardstick is **“journal-article grade, TeX-native aesthetics”**, then Codex’s plan (TeX → DVI → **dvisvgm** → inline SVG) will usually beat MathJax. But “better” depends on what you value besides looks. ## Visual quality: who wins? ### TeX → dvisvgm (Codex plan) **Usually best fidelity** because the layout is produced by a real TeX engine (line breaks, spacing, stretchy delimiters, radicals, accents, script placement) and then *converted*, not re-typeset by a JS engine. **Pros** - Closest to what you’d see in a TeX-produced PDF. - Very consistent across browsers (you’re shipping the final geometry). - Offline with **zero runtime dependencies** (no JS, no fonts to load). **Cons** - SVG math is often **not easily selectable/editable** as text. - Accessibility is weak unless you add extra layers (hidden MathML/alt text). - File size can balloon (lots of SVG path data), and many small inline SVGs can tax the DOM. ### MathJax MathJax renders math in the browser. It can look excellent, but it’s still an approximation of TeX layout with different font strategies. **Pros** - **Selectable/searchable** math (big win for studying/teaching). - Better **accessibility** (screen reader support, can generate MathML). - Smaller HTML if you keep TeX source and render at runtime (though MathJax itself is heavy unless you bundle it). **Cons** - Visual output can differ from TeX PDF: font feel, spacing, and some edge cases (especially dense scripts, uncommon macros, or certain font expectations). - Requires JS; if you want truly offline single-file, you must **inline MathJax + fonts/assets** (often very large), or accept additional local files. - First render cost can be noticeable on large documents. ## “More visually appealing” in practice - If your LaTeX uses **Computer Modern / Latin Modern**-ish expectations and you want “paper-like,” **TeX→SVG** tends to look more like a real paper. - If you want “web-native crisp + copyable,” MathJax (often **CommonHTML output**) is pleasant and practical, though slightly less “journal PDF” in vibe. ## Determinism + portability - **Codex plan is deterministic**: same SVG every time, no browser reflow surprises. - MathJax is *mostly* consistent but still depends on browser font metrics and rendering; usually fine, but not as “baked.” ## My recommendation (no hedging) ### If your priority is **journal-grade look + offline single file** Stick with Codex’s **pre-rendered SVG** approach. **But**: upgrade it slightly so it’s not a dead-end for usability: - For every SVG math chunk, also store the original TeX as: - `data-tex="..."` attribute, and/or - a hidden `...` for copy/search, and/or - `aria-label="..."` (at least something). - Consider embedding a hidden **MathML** representation if you care about accessibility (harder, but doable). ### If your priority is **reading, selecting, searching, accessibility** Use **MathJax**, and accept that it’s “web typesetting,” not a PDF clone. A strong hybrid (often best in real usage): - **Pre-render display math** (big equations) to SVG for perfect look. - Render **inline math** with MathJax (CommonHTML) for selectable text. This keeps the page fast-ish, readable, and still “paper-grade” where it matters. ## Quick critique of the plan you pasted (important) - The “lightweight LaTeX-to-HTML transform” will work for *your* controlled outputs, but it will be **brittle** the moment LaTeX gets fancy (nested macros, custom environments, complicated tables, \left...\right weirdness, etc.). - Tabular parsing with “split on `&` and `\\`” will break on common constructs (`\multicolumn`, `\cline`, `p{}`, `>{}` column specs). If your sessions include these, expect pain. If you tell me your typical math density + whether you care about copy/search/accessibility, I can give you a firm “choose A” and a minimal set of implementation tweaks (still fully offline, still deterministic).
I do not care about copy. But search/accessibility is impt. Also, my latex can be complicated

Given your constraints:

- **copy doesn’t matter**
- **search + accessibility matter**
- **LaTeX can be complicated**

…the “regex-ish LaTeX → HTML transform + TeX→SVG math” plan is the wrong foundation. It will break on real LaTeX, *and* pure SVG math is weak for accessibility/search unless you add an additional semantic layer.

### The core decision
For **complicated LaTeX**, you want an exporter that leverages a **real TeX-to-HTML workflow**, not a hand-rolled parser.

That narrows you to two sane families:

1) **TeX4ht / make4ht** (TeX engine-driven HTML conversion)  
2) **LaTeXML** (parser-based, excellent semantics, but macro compatibility varies depending on packages)

In practice, **TeX4ht (make4ht)** is usually the most robust “works with gnarly LaTeX” option because it runs TeX and hooks into the compilation process.

---

## Recommended architecture (robust + accessible + searchable)

### ✅ Best overall for your case: **make4ht + MathJax**
**Pipeline**
1. Use `make4ht` to convert the LaTeX document to HTML.
2. Keep math as TeX (or MathML depending on config).
3. Use **MathJax** in-page to render math and provide accessibility features.

**Why this fits your needs**
- **Complicated LaTeX**: TeX4ht is built for this kind of conversion.
- **Accessibility**: MathJax can generate/assist with MathML and screen-reader support.
- **Search**: searchable text + math source preserved; you can also add math indexing hooks.
- You avoid writing a fragile custom LaTeX parser.

**Tradeoff**
- If you want *single-file offline*, bundling MathJax into one HTML file is possible but can make the file big. (You can also ship a local folder; but you asked single-file earlier—this is the tension.)

---

## If you insist on TeX→SVG for “journal-grade” look
You can still do it, but you **must add a semantic layer** per equation.

### ✅ “Journal look” + accessibility/search: **SVG + hidden MathML/TeX**
For every rendered SVG formula, embed something like:

- a hidden `<math>` MathML node, OR
- a hidden plain text TeX string, plus `aria-label`, plus (optionally) a searchable index.

**Important warning:** SVG alone is not accessibility-friendly; you need at least one of:
- MathML (best for accessibility tooling)
- Assistive text / aria labels (second-best)
- A separate search index mapping tokens → locations

**How to get MathML**
- Either let **MathJax generate MathML** (even if you don’t use it to render), or
- use **LaTeXML** just for math fragments (less reliable for exotic macros), or
- accept TeX source as the semantic layer (not as good as MathML for screen readers, but searchable).

This hybrid is totally viable, but it’s more engineering than “render SVG and inline it.”

---

## What I would change in Codex’s plan (direct critique)
### 1) Drop the “lightweight LaTeX-to-HTML transform”
If your LaTeX can be complicated, this will become a never-ending whack-a-mole:
- macros, `\newcommand`, `\edef`, nested environments
- `tabular` features (`\multicolumn`, `\multirow`, `p{}`, `array` column specs, math in tables)
- `tcolorbox`, `tikz`, custom theorem environments, etc.

Instead: **use make4ht** to produce the HTML structure.

### 2) Treat accessibility/search as first-class output
If you go SVG math:
- store original TeX in `data-tex="..."`,
- add `aria-label="..."`,
- and ideally include hidden MathML (generated by MathJax or another tool).

### 3) Use MathJax even if you don’t “care about copy”
You care about accessibility/search; MathJax is one of the easiest ways to get that layer.

---

## Concrete recommendation (no extra questions)
**Do this:**
- Use **make4ht** as your LaTeX→HTML backbone (robust for complicated documents).
- Use **MathJax** for accessibility + math rendering (either CommonHTML or SVG output).
- If you still want maximum “journal look”, configure MathJax to **SVG output mode**, but keep its accessibility extensions enabled (so you get semantics).

That gives you:
- robust conversion for complex LaTeX,
- great accessibility,
- searchable math (at least as TeX, often as MathML),
- and very good visual output.

---

If you want, paste a snippet of the *most complicated* LaTeX constructs you expect (tables, theorem envs, tikz, custom macros). I’ll tell you which of **make4ht vs LaTeXML vs pandoc** is least likely to choke on *your* actual patterns, and what flags/config you should set.

`make4ht` is basically an **orchestrator** around the **TeX4ht** system. TeX4ht’s trick is: it doesn’t “parse LaTeX like a normal compiler would”; it **runs a real TeX engine** (LaTeX / XeLaTeX / LuaLaTeX) but with special hooks/macros that *redirect what would normally become typeset boxes* into **HTML tags + CSS + auxiliary files**.

Here’s the mental model.

## What actually happens under the hood

### 1) It runs a real TeX engine, but in “HTML-emitting mode”
When you run something like:

```bash
make4ht mydoc.tex
```

`make4ht` calls a TeX engine (often `latex`, `xelatex`, or `lualatex`) with TeX4ht-loaded configuration. That configuration:
- redefines many LaTeX macros/environments (`\section`, `\emph`, lists, floats, etc.)
- inserts “write HTML” instructions during compilation

So as TeX expands macros and builds the document, TeX4ht **writes HTML fragments** to output files (instead of only producing a DVI/PDF-like result).

### 2) The TeX run produces an intermediate “device” output + side files
Depending on engine:
- classic route: `latex` → **DVI**
- XeLaTeX: **XDV**
- LuaLaTeX route varies (often still workable via TeX4ht configs)

Along the way, TeX4ht writes:
- HTML body chunks
- CSS
- image references / generated images for things that can’t be represented as HTML/CSS directly
- metadata and mapping files that help assemble the final output

### 3) Post-processing assembles “real” HTML
After the TeX pass, TeX4ht tools (invoked by `make4ht`) stitch everything together:
- merges chunks into `mydoc.html` (or multiple HTML files if split)
- generates/adjusts CSS
- handles images (often via `dvisvgm` or other converters depending on settings)
- optionally runs tidy/cleanup filters

`make4ht` is the wrapper that decides **which steps to run**, **in what order**, with **which options**, for **which output format**.

## How complicated LaTeX survives better than regex conversion
Because TeX4ht is running a real TeX engine:
- Your macros expand the way they normally do.
- Packages that rely on TeX expansion logic still behave “TeX-correctly” (within TeX4ht support).
- You’re not trying to “understand LaTeX” with string processing; you’re piggybacking on TeX itself.

That’s why it’s usually much more robust than “strip preamble + regex sections + detect `$...$`”.

## What about math?
You get to choose policy:

- **Keep TeX math in the HTML and let MathJax render in the browser**  
  Best for accessibility/search/robustness.

- **Convert math to MathML (Mathematical Markup Language)** (sometimes possible; depends on config/packages)  
  Great for semantics, but the success rate depends on macros and tooling.

- **Convert math to SVG/PNG during export**  
  Best for “baked” look, worse for accessibility unless you add a semantic layer.

## One-liner summary
**`make4ht` produces HTML by running TeX normally, but with TeX4ht macros that intercept LaTeX structure and write HTML/CSS (plus images when needed), then it post-processes those files into final webpages.**

If you want, tell me your engine preference (pdfLaTeX vs XeLaTeX vs LuaLaTeX) and whether you want single-page or multi-page HTML, and I’ll suggest a sensible `make4ht` command + config strategy that maximizes compatibility with “complicated LaTeX.”
i want to Convert math to SVG/PNG during export, accessibility criteria can be downgraded

Cool — if you want **math baked into SVG/PNG at export time**, the cleanest route (especially with complicated LaTeX) is still to let **TeX4ht/make4ht** handle the document structure, and configure it so math is *not* left as TeX for MathJax, but instead converted during export. A few key points first: - **Prefer SVG over PNG** unless you have a specific reason. SVG scales crisply; PNG will blur/alias and inflate size. - Pure SVG math is **not great for accessibility/search**, but you said it can be downgraded. Still, I’d at least keep lightweight `alt`/`aria-label` with the original TeX as a cheap win. ## Best approach: make4ht + dvisvgm (math → SVG at export) ### How it works conceptually 1. make4ht runs LaTeX with TeX4ht hooks → generates HTML skeleton. 2. For math, TeX4ht can be configured to output math as images. 3. Those math images are generated via a converter pipeline; for SVG this is commonly **dvisvgm** (sometimes via DVI/XDV intermediates). ### Practical command to try Start with something like: ```bash make4ht -f html5+svg mydoc.tex ``` This “html5+svg” format is often the right starting point for SVG-oriented outputs. If you need to force the engine: ```bash make4ht -f html5+svg -l -d outdir mydoc.tex ``` Engine forcing varies by setup; if you’re using XeLaTeX/LuaLaTeX, you may need a slightly different config (because the intermediate may be XDV rather than DVI). But the above is the usual first shot. ## Where PNG comes in (if you really want PNG) PNG is typically produced via something like `dvipng` or by rendering PDF pages to bitmaps. That works, but it’s more “old school,” and output quality is worse at normal web zoom levels. If you do PNG: - choose a **high DPI** (e.g., 200–300) or it will look bad - expect bigger files ## What you should change in Codex’s current plan Since your LaTeX can be complicated, I’d flip the plan like this: ### Replace the “lightweight LaTeX-to-HTML transform” with TeX4ht - Don’t strip the preamble and regex your way through `\section`, `\tabular`, etc. - Let TeX4ht decide how to emit HTML for those constructs. - This alone will save you from 80% of the “complicated LaTeX” failure cases. ### Keep the “single-file HTML” requirement, but be realistic make4ht will naturally output: - an `.html` - a `.css` - images (math + figures) If you **must** have a single file: - do a final “pack” step that inlines CSS and base64-embeds images. - this is deterministic and straightforward. ## Minimal “pack into single HTML” post-step After make4ht finishes, you can run a packer script that: - reads the generated HTML - inlines the CSS `` - replaces `` with `data:image/svg+xml;base64,...` (or png base64) This keeps your existing “single-file offline” deliverable, but avoids hand-parsing LaTeX. ## Recommended policy choices (hard stance) - **Math as SVG**: yes - **Keep TeX source as alt text**: cheap and worth it (even if accessibility is downgraded) - **Document structure conversion**: use make4ht/TeX4ht, not custom parsing - **Tables**: let TeX4ht handle; don’t write your own tabular parser unless you enjoy suffering ## Caveats you should expect - Some packages/environments (notably heavy TikZ or certain custom class files) can still cause TeX4ht pain. - Math as SVG can produce lots of tiny `` elements; big documents may get heavy if you inline everything. (If you’re packing into one HTML, consider keeping SVG as external files unless you truly need one file.) --- If you want, paste: 1) the document class line (`\documentclass{...}`) and 2) your key packages list (or the preamble) …and I’ll suggest the most compatible `make4ht` format + flags, and how to keep math as SVG reliably on your setup (pdfLaTeX vs XeLaTeX vs LuaLaTeX).

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
Nice — this is a *very* TeX4ht-friendly preamble: `article`, `amsmath/amssymb`, `graphicx`, `geometry`, simple macros. You’re in the “should work out of the box” zone. ## What to do (math → SVG during export) ### 1) Basic run (HTML + SVG math/images) Try: ```bash make4ht -f html5+svg -d web_out real_numbers.tex ``` What you should see: - `web_out/real_numbers.html` - `web_out/real_numbers.css` (or similarly named) - SVG assets for math (often in a subfolder, depending on config) - Your `diagrams/*.png` copied/linked (or kept referenced) ### 2) If you want *all* images (including your diagrams) embedded later Keep make4ht’s output as multi-file, then do your existing “pack to single HTML” post-step (inline CSS + base64 images). That’s the clean separation: - make4ht handles LaTeX complexity correctly - your packer enforces “single-file offline” ## Why your document is easy for make4ht - `\section`, `\subsection`, `\tableofcontents` are first-class. - Display math `\[...\]` and inline math `$...$` are standard. - `\textbf{...}` maps cleanly. - `\newpage` becomes a break marker in HTML (not a true page break, but you can style it). - Your custom macro `\workingspace` is just rules + vspace; TeX4ht will likely translate it into some HTML-ish block (sometimes as images if it can’t map it cleanly). You can override this nicely (see below). ## Improve the one macro that matters: `\workingspace` Right now it’s “TeX layout”-ish. For web, you probably want it to become a semantic HTML div, like your Codex plan. You can do that with a small TeX4ht config file. ### Create `real_numbers.cfg` (or any name) alongside your `.tex` Put this in it: ```tex \Preamble{xhtml,svg} \Configure{workingspace}{\HCode{
}} \Css{ .workingspace{ margin: 0.5em 0; border-top: 1px solid #444; height: 40vh; /* default-ish */ } } \BeginDocument \EndPreamble ``` Then run: ```bash make4ht -c real_numbers.cfg -d web_out real_numbers.tex ``` This makes `\workingspace[...]` become HTML (instead of TeX spacing), which is what you want for a reflow page. *(If you want the optional argument `[#1]` to control height, that’s possible too, but it’s more TeX4ht macro plumbing. The simple fixed-height div is usually enough.)* ## SVG vs PNG for math - With `html5+svg`, math should come out as **SVG** (crisp). - PNG math is usually a downgrade unless you’re targeting ultra-old environments. ## If something goes wrong Common failure modes (and what they mean): - **“missing dvisvgm” / SVG not produced** → install `dvisvgm` in your TeX distribution. - **math becomes images but not SVG** → your format/config isn’t selecting SVG; use `-f html5+svg` or the `\Preamble{xhtml,svg}` config. - **geometry margins ignored** → normal; HTML isn’t paged. Use CSS margins instead. ## Single-file offline (the realistic way) make4ht won’t naturally emit a perfect single HTML with everything inlined. The sane workflow is: 1) `make4ht …` → correct HTML structure + SVG math assets 2) packer step → inline CSS + base64 embed images/SVG → `index.html` This is deterministic and keeps you away from brittle LaTeX parsing. If you paste a few more “hard” parts (tables, aligned environments, any custom environments), I can tell you what TeX4ht will do and where you might need 1–2 targeted configs.
So what instructions should I give codex?

thoughts.summary: Looking up make4ht instructions for TeX4ht pipeline

Once I have that, I'll draft clear, step-by-step guidance for integrating it into a pipeline, setting up config files, handling packing, ensuring accessibility, and managing diagrams.
chunks: I need to search the web for instructions on using make4ht with TeX4ht for SVG math configurations.
Once I have that, I'll draft clear, step-by-step guidance for integrating it into a pipeline, setting up config files, handling packing, ensuring accessibility, and managing diagrams.

metadata.reasoning_title: Searching for make4ht configuration and setup instructions

parts:
Give Codex instructions to **stop hand-parsing LaTeX** and instead use **make4ht/TeX4ht as the LaTeX→HTML backend**, configured to **render math as SVG during export**, then (optionally) do a deterministic **“pack to single-file HTML”** step. Here’s a concrete instruction set you can paste to Codex. --- ## Instructions to Codex ### Goal Export `/.tex` to a **reflowed HTML page** where **math is pre-rendered to SVG** at export time (no MathJax at runtime), and diagrams are embedded (optionally base64 inline) to allow fully offline viewing. ### Why this approach - Your LaTeX can be complicated → regex/handwritten parsing will break. - make4ht/TeX4ht runs a real TeX engine and is designed for LaTeX→HTML conversion (robust), including image generation for math/complex constructs. citeturn0search9turn0search10turn0search8 --- ## Implementation plan (do this, not the old plan) ### 1) New exporter uses `make4ht` instead of custom LaTeX parsing Add module: `pdf_to_latex/web_exporter.py` Implement: - Read source `tex_path = session_dir / f"{pdf_stem}.tex"`. - Run `make4ht` into a temp output folder: `out_dir = session_dir / "_web_tmp"` (or build folder). - Use **HTML5 + SVG** format so math is produced as SVG via TeX4ht’s image pipeline (dvisvgm). Start with: ```bash make4ht -f html5+svg -d ``` This is the canonical “HTML5 with SVG” target. citeturn0search9turn0search10 > Note: TeX4ht can convert “complicated math” to images; make4ht’s docs explicitly describe image conversion support. citeturn0search8turn0search9 ### 2) Provide a TeX4ht config to map `\workingspace` to HTML (optional but recommended) Create a TeX4ht config file on the fly (write it into the temp folder) and pass via `-c`. Example config content: - Use an XHTML/HTML5 preamble with SVG enabled. - Override `\workingspace` to emit `
…
` (so it becomes web-semantic, not a TeX vertical skip). (TeX4ht configuration is a standard mechanism; make4ht supports config-driven customization. citeturn0search5turn0search9) ### 3) CSS handling Option A (simplest): keep the CSS file generated by make4ht next to the HTML. Option B (single-file): use make4ht’s inline CSS format and then remove the leftover `` tag if present: ```bash make4ht -f html5+svg+inlinecss -d ``` Inline-CSS is supported via make4ht tooling/filters, but may still leave the `` tag, so do a deterministic post-pass that removes it. citeturn0search2turn0search9 ### 4) Single-file HTML (if required) After make4ht produces `*.html` + assets: - Parse the HTML (use a real HTML parser, not regex). - Inline CSS (if not already inlined). - For every `` that points to local files: - read bytes - replace with `data:image/svg+xml;base64,...` or `data:image/png;base64,...` - For SVG assets referenced as `

parts:
These instructions? ### Goal Export `/.tex` to a **reflowed HTML page** where **math is pre-rendered to SVG** at export time (NOTE: no MathJax at runtime), and diagrams are embedded (base64 inline) to allow fully offline viewing. ### Why this approach * make4ht/TeX4ht runs a real TeX engine and is designed for LaTeX→HTML conversion (robust), including image generation for math/complex constructs. --- ## Implementation plan (do this, not the old plan) ### 1) New exporter uses `make4ht` instead of custom LaTeX parsing Add module: `pdf_to_latex/web_exporter.py` Implement: * Read source `tex_path = session_dir / f"{pdf_stem}.tex"`. * Run `make4ht` into a temp output folder: `out_dir = session_dir / "_web_tmp"` (or build folder). * Use **HTML5 + SVG** format so math is produced as SVG via TeX4ht’s image pipeline (dvisvgm). Note: TeX4ht can convert “complicated math” to images; make4ht’s docs explicitly describe image conversion support. ### Improve the one macro that matters: `\workingspace` Right now it’s “TeX layout”-ish. For web, you probably want it to become a semantic HTML div. You can do that with a small TeX4ht config file. #### Create `real_numbers.cfg` (or any name) alongside your `.tex` Put this in it: ```tex \Preamble{xhtml,svg} \Configure{workingspace}{\HCode{
}} \Css{ .workingspace{ margin: 0.5em 0; border-top: 1px solid #444; height: 40vh; /* default-ish */ } } \BeginDocument \EndPreamble ``` Then run: ```bash make4ht -c real_numbers.cfg -d web_out real_numbers.tex ``` This makes `\workingspace[...]` become HTML (instead of TeX spacing), which is what you want for a reflow page. *(If you want the optional argument `[#1]` to control height, that’s possible too, but it’s more TeX4ht macro plumbing. The simple fixed-height div is usually enough.)* ### 2) Provide a TeX4ht config to map `\workingspace` to HTML Create a TeX4ht config file on the fly (write it into the temp folder) and pass via `-c`. Example config content: * Use an XHTML/HTML5 preamble with SVG enabled. * Override `\workingspace` to emit `
…
` (so it becomes web-semantic, not a TeX vertical skip). (TeX4ht configuration is a standard mechanism; make4ht supports config-driven customization.) ### 3) CSS handling Use make4ht’s inline CSS format and then remove the leftover `` tag if present: Inline-CSS is supported via make4ht tooling/filters, but may still leave the `` tag, so do a deterministic post-pass that removes it. ### 4) Single-file HTML After make4ht produces `*.html` + assets: * Parse the HTML (use a real HTML parser, not regex). * Inline CSS (if not already inlined). * For every `` that points to local files: * read bytes * replace with `data:image/svg+xml;base64,...` or `data:image/png;base64,...` * For SVG assets referenced as `

Yes — **that’s basically the right set of instructions**. I’d tighten/adjust a few things so Codex doesn’t get tripped up by TeX4ht details and so the deliverable is unambiguous. Below is a **cleaned, Codex-ready version** (same intent, fewer footguns). You can paste this as-is. --- ### Goal Export `/.tex` to a **reflowed single-file HTML** where: - **Math is pre-rendered to SVG during export** (no MathJax runtime rendering). - Diagrams and any generated assets are **base64-inlined** so the result opens fully offline. - LaTeX may be complicated → do **not** hand-parse LaTeX. --- ## Implementation plan ### 1) Use make4ht/TeX4ht as the LaTeX→HTML engine (no custom parsing) Create `pdf_to_latex/web_exporter.py` with: - `export_session_to_web(session_dir, out_html, title, strict=False, single_file=True)` Steps: 1. Locate `tex_path = session_dir / f"{pdf_stem}.tex"`. Fail clearly if missing. 2. Create temp dir: `tmp_dir = session_dir / "_web_tmp"` (clear/recreate). 3. Run make4ht targeting HTML5 + SVG: ```bash make4ht -f html5+svg -d -c ``` - If make4ht returns nonzero and `strict=True`, raise error. - If `strict=False`, still produce best-effort output if HTML exists, otherwise error. ### 2) Provide a TeX4ht config file (generated on the fly) Write a TeX4ht config into `/export.cfg` and pass `-c export.cfg`. Config requirements: - Ensure SVG math/images output. - Map `\workingspace` to semantic HTML (not TeX vertical space). Config template (use this): ```tex \Preamble{xhtml,svg} \Configure{workingspace}{\HCode{
}} \Css{ .workingspace{ margin: 0.5em 0; border-top: 1px solid #444; height: 40vh; } } \begin{document} \EndPreamble ``` (If `\Configure{workingspace}` doesn’t catch it in practice, fallback: redefine the macro for this export by injecting `\renewcommand{\workingspace}[1][]{...}` in a temporary wrapper .tex, but only if needed.) ### 3) Make output deterministic & offline After make4ht finishes, identify the main HTML file in ``: - Prefer `.html` if present, else pick the newest `.html`. Then post-process: - Inline any linked CSS (``) by replacing with ``. - Base64-inline all local assets referenced by: - `` - `
